Dialogue.Stage Direction: A long, shadowed corridor adjacent to the Temple of Castor. IMPERIAL NOTICES and scandalous ADVERTISEMENTS are pinned haphazardly to the walls, juxtaposed against the austere Roman religious decor. The air is thick with the scent of incense and something else... something less holy.
CLAUDIUS, a middle-aged man with a stammer, stands with CALPURNIA, a woman of refined beauty, examining a small scroll.

Dialogue.Line: It's from Herod.
What does he say?
Oh, it's written from J-Jerusalem.
Read it to me. His letters are so amusing.

"My dear old friend, what is all this I hear about you living in three rooms in the p-poor quarter of town? Is it serious? Why did you not write to me? Is it that absurd p-pride of yours? Well, I shall attend to that shortly. Meanwhile, knowing how loath you are to accept money and being the only p-practical friend you ever had, I enclose a little p-p-present for you. Please make proper use of it. Herod."  Calpurnia leans in, peering at a small object.
What is it? It seems very small.
Well, I don't know.
Well, I don't think that's very generous... Venus! Oh, Claudius, I think your luck is changing. I'm sure it's an omen! ... Those dice are crooked. You can't possibly use them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: chuckles

Dialogue.Line: HaHaHa. Oh, dear Herod! How I miss him.  BRISEIS, a young servant girl, rushes in, agitated.
Master. Master, have you seen this?
What?
It was pinned on the door of the temple of Castor.
What is it?
It's advertising a brothel in the palace! They're all over the city.  Calpurnia looks genuinely shocked.
A brothel? In the palace? But... But who is to serve in it?
His sisters, his cousins, senators and their wives.
You knew about it?
Yes.
Why didn't you tell me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: beat

Dialogue.Line: He wants you there?
He wants me to take the m-money on the door.
Oh, Claudius.
The monster. The little monster. Forcing the nobility into prostitution. And in the palace! Why, even Calpurnia wouldn't serve in such a place, and that's her profession!
Briseis, that is not her profession any more!
My dear, that was and is my profession. I'm a prostitute and I've never been ashamed of it.
All the same, I won't serve in his brothel! Either as d-doorkeeper or as chucker out. There's some price a man won't pay.

Scenes.Scene: INT. IMPERIAL PALACE - RECEPTION HALL - NIGHT

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ornate and bustling. A chamber where commerce and politics intertwine. A constant flow of people, money, and whispered deals. The air is thick with the scent of perfume, sweat, and ambition.

SABINUS, a worried-looking man in his late twenties, stands nervously with DIANA, his young wife. She clutches his arm, terrified. They stand before CLAUDIUS, who is positioned near an archway leading deeper into the palace.

Dialogue.Line: Claudius, I was told to bring her here but she's terrified.
Well, there's nothing you can do.
Claudius please listen. She's given birth six weeks ago. If somebody in there touches her I'm afraid of what she'll do.
There are no exceptions.
There must be a room or somewhere to put her. No one will notice. Please!
Do you want my throat cut along with yours? Now you've paid your fee, go on in! Enjoy yourself.
Come, it's not important.
No!
Do you want the child left without a mother? Come.  POPPAEA, a strikingly beautiful woman, approaches, oozing confidence and malice. She assesses Diana with a predatory gaze.

Ah, another customer. And we were just running out of men. Haha, real men. Sabinus, isn't it? And I see you've brought your pretty wife. My dear, you'll make a fortune in there tonight. You'd better, anyway. The Emperor has just raised his commission. Shall we go?  MARCUS, a portly man with a lecherous grin, arrives, eyeing Diana hungrily.
Ah, reinforcements.
Marcus Vinicius, the Emperor's brother-in-law and your first customer. Make him pay through the nose, my dear. You're worth it.
No!
Come.  Marcus reaches for Diana. Claudius steps forward, grabbing Marcus's arm.
What are you doing?
Chucking you out!
But you've no right!
That's what I'm here for and that's what I'm doing.
But why?
For creating a disturbance.
But she was creating the disturbance, you fool!
Out! See him off the premises. ...  Claudius gestures to guards who seize Marcus and drag him away. He turns back to Diana, his expression softening.
Go on. Go home.
But if the Emperor should return?
I'll tell him I threw you out for indecent behavior.  CAESONIA, Caligula's wife, enters. She is heavily pregnant and her face is etched with worry.
You are a good man, Claudius.
Oh.
Claudius. We must help him, the Emperor.
He's your husband. You help him!
Claudius. He's sick. He needs good people around him.
He's killed them all! Look, what are you doing here in your condition?
He told me to come. He likes me to be with him.

Has he shown you, naked, to his G-German guards lately? Oh, I'm sorry, Caesonia. It's not for me to criticize. I bleat with the rest of them whenever he appears. There are no lions among us any more.  **SOUND** of a struggle.  A YOUNG MAN is dragged into the hall by GUARDS.
What are you doing? Let me go!  CALIGULA strides in, laughing maniacally. He is dressed in flamboyant attire, his eyes burning with madness.
HaHaHa. "Vulcan, with awkward grace his office plies, while unextinguished laughter shakes the skies." Homer. For "Vulcan" read "Old Uncle Claudius".
Oh...Ah... "Then, from his anvil, the lame craftsman rose... Wide... with distorted legs, oblique he goes."

Oh, bravo! Henceforth, Uncle, you shall be Vulcan. While I... Oh, what am I... but Ulysses returning home to witness the shame and degradation of his household. ... Cassius. Did you ever see a sight as sad and degrading as this?  CASSIUS, a stern-faced officer, stands impassively behind Caligula.
Shall I arrest them, Caesar?

No, let them indulge themselves a while longer. Soon, I promise you, I shall flush this sewage into the Tiber forever. Meanwhile, Jove must cleanse himself in battle. I have sworn to fight a war against the Germans that will end in their total annihilation. And I shall bring back much booty to Rome, fill her coffers, enrich her purse. Cassius, order the detachments and raise the levies! I go to forge, in the white-hot fires of war, a new and tempered spirit of Rome that will last a thousand years!  Caesonia approaches Claudius, subtly knocking on his arm to get his attention.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: knocking

Dialogue.Line: Claudius!
Well, I brought a little g-gift for the baby.
Oh, Claudius. That's lovely. Show it to her.  They move to a quieter corner of the hall. Caesonia gestures towards a bassinet.
How is she?
Come and see.  Claudius peers into the bassinet.
Ah, there. She's very pretty. Yes, she looks just like you.
Come and sit down. So, how is Calpurnia?
Oh, she's well. She sends her felicitations. I'm going to see the Emperor in Germany soon so I shall be able to report that you're both looking well.
Why are you going to Germany?
Haven't you heard?
Oh, you know they tell me nothing.

Oh, oh. I... I'm not sure I should tell you. Oh well, I suppose you'll hear about it soon enough. Well, he has informed the Senate by letter that he has uncovered a v-vast conspiracy against himself in the army of the Rhine. Six corps commanders and the army commander himself, Gaetulicus, have been executed. More executions are still taking place.
Do you think there was a conspiracy?
Oh, who knows? Would it surprise you? But Gaetulicus? No. He was my father's old friend, my brother's corps commander, a soldier of iron loyalties. No, that's not possible.
Why are you going, then?

The Senate is sending me, and two ex-Consuls, to congratulate him on the s-suppression of the mutiny. As I said, the only lions left in Rome are in the arena. I'm also to strip Livia's apartments of all their valuables and send them to him by road. Oh, he stresses by road. Apparently, he has a quarrel with Neptune and fears the boat will sink.
What does he want them for?
Well, to auction to the provincials. He's auctioning everything at the moment. He's discovered he has a gift for it.
Claudius, what am I doing here? Why did he choose me for a wife? I'm ten years older than he is, not pretty. I was born the daughter of a night-watchman, I married a baker. What does he see in me?
Perhaps that you, alone among everyone... truly l-love him.
Yes, I do love him. I can't explain why. I know he does terrible things. I'll tell you something. He is more afraid than any of us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sunlight streams through the high windows of a grand, yet chaotic, audience chamber. Maps are strewn across tables, and OFFICERS rush about, their faces etched with worry. Through the windows, the Tiber River flows restlessly.
CALIGULA (20s), stands imperiously, his eyes wild. CASSIUS (40s), a hardened soldier, stands rigidly beside him.

Dialogue.Line: Cassius! I've just been talking to that river god. He threatened to drown me.
Does he know who you are?
Oh, he does now. I've just given him a severe reprimand. He'll soon shudder. Well, the river's going down, isn't it?
Yes, Caesar. Your uncle is here with Marcus Vinicius and Asprenas.
Let them in.  The doors open, and CLAUDIUS (50s), MARCUS VINICIUS (40s), and ASPRENAS (40s) enter hesitantly. Claudius bows deeply.
Hail Caesar, Lord of the Heavens. The Senate and the people of Rome...
Where are my carts?
C-carts?
The carts, you idiot, with the valuables in them.
Oh, heaven bless Your Majesty, they're coming by road. They'll be a few days yet. We wanted to get here as soon, so we came across the water.
Oh, then back by water you'll go! Throw him in the river!
Oh, merciful god!
How dare you arrive without my carts?
But you only said the carts should come by road!
Take him onto the bridge and throw him off!  Caligula gestures wildly. Marcus and Asprenas shrink back, terrified.

Prostrate yourselves in the presence of Jove! How dare the Senate send that idiot to congratulate me! I'll have their throats cut. He's not worthy of such a mission. The man's an imbecile! I save Rome from a conspiracy and they send that clapped-out crippled old clown to felicitate me? Is that the respect that they give their Emperor? What's going on there? More plots, more conspiracies. I'll set my German guards on them when I get back. I'll burn the damn place down! It never was any use! Yes. I should have done that a long time ago. I should have had his throat cut when I was first made emperor. I mean, he makes a mess of everything! He couldn't even order my brothers statues on time.
Merciful god, we only came by sea to bring our congratulations sooner.
I wanted carts, not congratulations! Up! Up! Up! Up!  Caligula paces erratically, his eyes darting about.

Did I not tell you that I've had a quarrel with Neptune? That he plagues me all the time with his sea noises, stirs the river gods up against me and makes war on me everywhere. How dare you ride with him!  He glares at Marcus and Asprenas.
Perhaps... Yes... Perhaps you plotted with him.
No, merciful god.
Yes, you and that imbecile uncle of mine, you plotted with him on your way here.
No, highest one, we assure you...
What did you talk about, then? You and Neptune? What did you say to one another?
Nothing, we swear! Mere mortals can't talk to a god!
Perhaps he appeared to you in mortal guise as I do. What did he look like?
We never saw him. Oh, please believe me. He wouldn't plot with us.
Perhaps you're right. But I shall kill you just the same. Down!  Caligula grabs CASSIUS' sword.
Cassius, give me your sword.
Oh, please! In the name of my wife, your sister...
How dare you mention that whore to me?
But what have we done?

I'll show the Senate what I think of their envoys! I'll send you back to Rome in pieces. I wish I hadn't thrown my uncle into the river now. I could've done the same with him but never mind, they'll get the message.
No!  CALIGULA (laughing) And where have you been, my dear, dear Vulcan?

Oh... "I felt the Thunderer's might, Hurled headlong down from the ethereal height, Breathless I fell, in giddy motions lost. The Sinthians raised me on the Lemnian coast." For "Lemnian" read "Rhenium".
Oh, by Jove! Which is always to say "by myself", this fellow knows his Homer.
Please, Claudius, beseech the Emperor to save our lives.
"Be silent and obey! Dear as you are, if Jove his arm extend, I can but grieve, unable to defend."
Look, if the next two lines are apt, then they're saved. If not, I'll have their throats cut.
Oh, what... Oh!  He fumbles with the scroll.
"What soul so daring in your aid to move, Or lift his arm against the might of Jove?" For "Jove" read "C-C..."

Me! Oh, he's got a line for everything. Come on get up. You're saved. Saved by Claudius' ready tongue. HaHaHa. Come into the other room. I'll give you a blanket. Oh, Cassius.  Caligula claps Cassius on the shoulder and starts to exit.
Cassius.
What is the watchword for tonight, Caesar?
Oh. The watchword for tonight? Let me see. What about "Give us a kiss"?  Caligula exits, laughing. Cassius' face remains impassive.
It could have been just now. It could happen tomorrow or the next day to you or to me. But do not doubt it will happen one day.
Did that surprise you, the watchword that I gave to Cassius Chaerea?
Oh, I t-thought it was a j-j-joke.
Well, it was, but it's my joke, not his. I do it to annoy him. Every time he addresses a commander of the guard, he has to say "Give us a kiss"! Yesterday, I gave him "Touch me, Titus"!
Why, if I m-may ask, d-do you do that?
Because he's a cry-baby.
Cassius? I thought he was the b-bravest soldier in the army.

Oh, so did I, but he's not. I had him torture Gaetulicus to get some information out of him.., and Gaetulicus... Well we got no information out of him and he died under torture, and one of the guards told me that Cassius wept. Well, I was going to give him Macro's command, but I certainly didn't after that. How many hours a night do you sleep?
Sleep? Oh, eight or n-nine, I suppose.
Well, I sleep barely three!
Do g-g-gods need more?
Do you think I'm mad?
M-m-mad?
Yes. Sometimes I think that I'm going mad. Do you...? Oh no, be honest with me, has that thought ever crossed your mind?
Never. N-never. Why, the idea is preposterous! You set the standard of s-sanity for the whole world.
Then why is there all this galloping in my head? And why do I sleep so little?

Well, um... it's your mortal disguise. You see, a physical b-body is a great strain if you're not used to it... which a god isn't. Um, err... And that explains too, I think... um... the three hours sleep. You see, undisguised gods never sleep at all

Yes, you're probably right. But then if I'm a god, which of course I am, then why didn't I think of that? Anyway, whatever the reason, it's very hard to be a god. Oh, you do know that I am that all-powerful god whose coming the Jews have prophesied for centuries?
Oh, yes, yes, you told me. I feel very p-privileged to receive that information, especially as the Jews, apparently, don't know it.
Yes, but it's prophesied that he'll die young and hated by his own people.
No, I can't believe that. No. Not hated.

It's incredible, isn't it? It must be true. Uncle, I want you to come with us on this expedition. When we've auctioned the stuff in the carts... When they arrive! We shall cross the Rhine, defeat the Germans and then we shall march towards the sea and I shall do battle with my old enemy Neptune, and oh what triumphs I shall have when we return to Rome. Now you may leave me. I have a headache.  Caligula dismisses Claudius with a wave of his hand. Claudius bows deeply and exits, leaving Caligula alone, staring out at the river. The camera lingers on Cassius's face, a mask of grim determination.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An expansive, marble-lined hall leads to the public streets of Rome. The expected triumph has soured into muted anger and disillusionment. CALIGULA, in ornate battle regalia, stands before a group of SENATORS, their faces a mixture of fear and resentment. CLAUDIUS and CAESONIA stand nearby, observing.
SOUND: of distant, sparse applause

Dialogue.Line: The seeds of discontent were sown that day, watered by Caligula's madness and the Senate's cowardice.

Your Emperor is amongst you once again. All his wars successfully concluded and the victorious armies brought back to Rome. He had thought, in his divine innocence... that the roads might be lined with cheering crowds. He had thought that the streets might be strewn with flowers. He had thought that there might be messages to greet him telling him of triumphs to be awarded. What did he find? This conqueror of the Germans, this victor over the mighty Neptune? The streets empty of crowds and flowers, no triumphs awarded, no Games, no celebrations... but three miserable old ex-Consuls waiting at the gates to greet him and a room full of cowardly stay-at-home senators, who spent all their time in the theatre and at the baths, while he has spent six months living no better than a private soldier! Yes, your Emperor has returned... but with this in his hand!  Caligula brandishes a handful of SEASHELLS.
But, Jove, you ordered no triumphs.
Well, of course I ordered no triumphs! Do you think I'd order triumphs for myself?
But you ordered us not to order any.

Yes, and you took me at my word, didn't you? Typical! It didn't occur to you that I might be leaving it up to you for your love to show itself freely? It didn't occur to you that it might be my natural humility speaking? I ordered you not to celebrate. But you ordered celebrations for the anniversary of Actium, didn't you? Didn't forget to celebrate the defeat of my great-grandfather Mark Antony! How many bottles of wine did you open toasting his murder while I was doing battle with the sea? Show them our booty! Show them the plunder we gathered from old Neptune.
Sea-shells?
Yes. Spoils of the sea. Loot from old Neptune. He won't take me on again in a hurry.
Jove, while you were away, we built a new temple to you on Palatine Hill.
That won't save you! Down on your knees, all of you! Bend your heads. I shall sever each one at the neck!  Caligula raises his hand as if to strike. The Senators cower. Claudius steps forward.

Merciful god! Would you spoil the great day of your return by the spilling of blood? When they come to write the history of this memorable day should they have to mix it with the memory of the death of these fools?

Claudius is right, my Lord. My husband. Think of your little daughter. One day when she is older, she will read the account of your return. Must these fools intrude on such a glorious page of history?  Caligula hesitates, then lowers his hand. He looks at Caesonia, a flicker of affection in his eyes.

Your soft words have appeased my wrath. As we know, prayer can soften the hearts of gods. You may go. I shall inspect the temple in the morning.  The Senators scramble to their feet and quickly exit. MARCUS VINICIUS approaches Caligula.
How right you were, Jove, to think of punishing them for celebrating the battle of Actium.
Well you see Marcus, I had them both ways. Because if they hadn't, they would have insulted the god Augustus, my grandfather, who won the battle.
And Agrippa too, who was also there and was your other grandfather...  Caligula's face darkens. He stares at Marcus with cold fury.
Marcus Vinicius, you are no longer my friend.
What have I said?
You reminded him that Agrippa was his grandfather.
But Agrippa was a great man!
Yes, but of very l-low birth. Such men do not produce gods, Marcus. Certainly not ones capable of d-defeating Neptune.  CASSIUS, who has been lurking in the background, steps forward.
If you're no longer his friend, what can you be but his enemy?
Go your own way, Cassius.
If we all go our own way, we shall all end by going the same way.  Cassius gives Marcus a knowing look, then turns and exits. Marcus watches him go, a look of unease on his face.

Scenes.Scene: INT. PALACE - ELABORATE RECEPTION ROOM/DANCING PAVILION - DAWN

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lavishly decorated, the room echoes with the last strains of a Greek ballet rehearsal. Light filters through the windows as dawn breaks. CLAUDIUS is startled by loud knocking.
O.S., loud knocking

Dialogue.Line: Yes. I'm coming! Oh, yes, yes, I'm coming, I'm coming, I'm coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CALPURNIA (O.S.) is in a state of agitation.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Claudius, don't go. They could be assassins.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: opening door cautiously

Dialogue.Line: Who are you? What do you want?  CASSIUS (O.S.) You're wanted at the palace!
Is that you, Cassius?
Yes. Hurry up.
W-Well, what's the matter?
My orders are to fetch you at once. MARCUS VINICIUS and ASPRENAS too. Never mind about dressing just throw on a cloak.

Scenes.Scene: INT. PALACE - RECEPTION ROOM/DANCING PAVILION - DAY

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CLAUDIUS, MARCUS, and ASPRENAS sit huddled. They are clearly anxious. The remnants of the dance performance are still visible.

Dialogue.Line: How long...? How long have we been sitting here, do you think?
About t-t-two hours. It must be nearly light.
What do you think he's going to do with us?
I don't know. I j-just hope it's q-quick, that's all.
Claudius, I'm sorry I've made fun of you in the past.
Oh, it doesn't m-matter now.
Will you give me your hand?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: extending his hand

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, that's a great comfort to me.  A SINGER continues a performance. It's haunting and beautiful.

Whenever the God of Night sleeps on.. The rosy-fingered goddess, Dawn.. Tiptoes on his domain.. And then she flits across the skies from star to star about.. She lightens darkness where she flies and blows Night's candles out.. Raging on her heels Night treads.. And tries to hold her fast.. And bring her loveliness to bed and ravish her at last.. And every night he once contrives to win a single kiss.. To win a single kiss.. Before the morning sun arrives.. To rob him of his bliss.. And now she turns and lightly treads.. On pillows everywhere.. She must awaken from their beds.. The secret lovers there.. But loath to part they linger there.. She urges them away.. Oh, Dawn, of goddesses most fair.. We worship you each day.. We worship you each day!  CLAUDIUS, genuinely moved, applauds enthusiastically. CALIGULA watches him with amusement.
Oh, god of gods! Never have I witnessed a dance that gave me such p-profound s-spiritual joy!
Oh. Did you like it?
It was indesc-cribable.
Well, it was only a rehearsal.
Oh. W-whatever will the f-finished performance be like?
Get up. Come here.  Caligula gestures for Claudius to approach. He scrutinizes Claudius.
What did you think of the girl?
Oh, b-beautiful.
You old lecher!  Caligula claps his hands.
Bring the girl back! I'm going to marry her to you tomorrow!
T-t-to me?

Mmm. I think it'd be very funny. All that loveliness married to a silly crippled old fool like you. I mean, what on earth would you do with it?  He gestures to MESSALINA, who enters, looking apprehensive.
Oh, Messalina, come here. I'm going to marry you... to Uncle Claudius! And you can both come and live in the palace.
Thank you, Caesar.
And now I must away to shed more light. Oh, Cassius! Oh, yes. The watchword for tonight. "Bottoms up!"  Caligula exits, laughing. Marcus is appalled.
I give you another watchword - "Liberty".
I'm s-s-sorry.
Don't you want to marry me?
Well, it's j-just that I'm so much older than you.

I'd be very happy to be married to you. To tell you the truth, I was terrified when he brought me here. I thought he was going to... I'd feel safe being married to you. Do you think you could ever love me?
I think... I'm in l-l-love with you already.
Well, if I'm to be married tomorrow, I must go home and get ready. Goodbye, Claudius.
G-g-g... g-goodbye.  An USHER enters.
Tiberius Claudius Drusus Nero Germanicus, his family and friends.
Welcome, Tiberius Claudius Drusus Nero Germanicus, to you and your family and your friends.
I thank you, V-Valeria Messalina, for my family and my friends. And I thank you for m-myself.

The noble senator Incitatus.  CALIGULA (O.S.) You know everybody, don't you? Well, find yourself a place. He's never been to a wedding before. His life has really opened up since I made him a senator. Well, let the auspices be taken.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Shadows cling to the walls of a narrow, secluded corridor behind the Imperial box. CASSUIS, a hardened soldier, paces impatiently before MARCUS and ASPRENAS.

Dialogue.Line: Kill him. We've talked enough. I say kill him.
It's risky.
You can't kill a man without taking a risk.
But those German guards never leave him.
There's always a way. But are you with us? Or will you wait till he offers you poisoned fruit or has your throat cut at dinner?
It's all right for you, you're a soldier.
Yes. You can leave the killing to me. But will you help?
He's right, Marcus. The longer we leave it, the more certain it is we shan't survive.
All right. But when and where?
Tomorrow is the final day of the Games. Let's do it then.
Where?
There's a covered way at the rear of the Imperial box. It's an exit you must persuade him to use.
How?
Find a reason. Tell him there are crowds out front and they'll delay his meal.
He'll have his German guards with him.

Yes. Now, here's the tricky part. Sabinus and I will be waiting outside. You'll be in the box with CALIGULA and a few friends. Normally, he would lead the way out, followed by his friends and then the guards. The staircase down to the covered way is narrow. You must be sure to be behind Caligula. As he steps out, into the covered way, you must stumble or drop something, anything to give us time to slam the gates from the outside and separate Caligula from the guards. That's all you have to do.
And then what?
We call on the Senate to declare a Republic and put an end to this madness.
Who dies with Caligula?
The whole Imperial family, CAESONIA, the child, the two sisters... and dear old Uncle CLAUDIUS and his new wife.
No, I don't want that.
We must! Whatever they think of Caligula, they won't rest until they removed his assassins. None of us would be safe afterwards.
It's Caligula alone or not at all
All right. Just Caligula.
Liberty and the Republic.
I don't like it. It's dangerous to leave the others alive.
We shan't. I'll see to that, don't worry. If they're in for Caligula, they're in for the lot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CALIGULA throws dice, losing money. CLAUDIUS, ever obsequious, watches with feigned concern.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, damn! I've lost all my money! I'm not playing any more.
Here, Lord, let me lend you some.
Lend? You know how I hate running up debt.
Oh... well, have half of my set...
Accepted. ... Why am I so unlucky today! Unless of course it's your dice I'm playing with.
My dice? Why should my dice be any different from any other?

Oh, a dice is a very personal thing. One man's dice may be lucky for himself, but not for his friend. Here, Lord, try these. They were sent to me by Herod. He claims they once belonged to Alexander the G-Great.
Really? I'd no idea that Alexander played dice.
He had many things in common with you, Lord.  **SOUND** of a crowd roaring.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: startled

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
He's got the Thracian down. The crowd want him spared, they've turned their thumbs up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: thumbs down, crowd boos

Dialogue.Line: The Thracian? If they only had one neck, I'd hack it through. ... I never did like that Thracian. He's lost me a lot of money over the last year. Alexander, you say? Well, let's see. By Jove, which is always to say "by myself", that looks promising. Come one, pay up, everybody. I think I'm indebted to you, Uncle. You've changed my luck.
Oh, some dice are fit only for gods to throw.
What about something to eat? Is Caesar hungry?
No. ... Oh, I see what you mean! These dice were made for me. Come on, pay up again. You did me a lot of harm with those dice, Marcus. And I'm raising the stakes to 3,000.
I've r-run out of money, Lord.
Well, that doesn't matter. Your new wife's got plenty. I'll take an IOU. Come on, pay up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CASSIUS checks his sword. SABINUS looks nervous.

Dialogue.Line: I've posted guards at both ends and told them to prevent anyone coming through here.
They'll be out soon.
I've dismissed the palace guards. They're all at the Games.
Will you strike the first blow?
Jove himself couldn't stop me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CALIGULA, flush with victory, stares at the others.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I can see you don't want to play any more. You only like playing when you're winning. Shall we watch the Games for a while?
What about a swim and then something to eat?
No, I don't think so. I don't feel very hungry today but I've had a wonderful morning, Uncle, thanks to you.. Is there any small favor I could grant you?
Oh, Lord, please, regard it as a small return for the g-great happiness you've given me with my new wife.
Happiness? She wasn't supposed to make you happy, nor you her. It was meant to be a joke!

Oh, no, no. You misunderstand me. No, I'm so clumsy at expressing myself. No, no. What I meant was that my happiness comes from contemplating yours. To be the cause of s-so much merriment is the source of d-deepest satisfaction to me.
Where are you going, Marcus?
To tell the truth, Lord, nature calls. It must've been something I ate last night.
Don't look at me. If I decide to doctor your food, you won't have to wait until morning to find out. ... That's odd. He wanted to eat a moment ago. His behavior's very strange lately.
Strange?
Well, nervous. What has he got to be nervous about?
We're all nervous in your presence, Lord.
I've never been able to understand that. ... Excuse me. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: MARCUS bursts in, sweating.

Dialogue.Line: He doesn't want to eat. We'll have to put it off, it won't work.
Then I'll go in and kill him where he sits!
They'll cut you down.
What's that to me? But I'll call on you for help before they do.
No, wait! I'll tell him his Greek ballet have arrived. He'll come out for that.
Anything. But get him out here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: MARCUS returns, trying to appear nonchalant.

Dialogue.Line: Lord, Cassius informs me your Greek ballet is here.
Greek ballet? Where are they?
Waiting outside to greet you.
Bring them in and present them. Oh, just the boys. The girls can wait.
Lord, they say that they have prepared a dance in your honor which they wish to perform for you outside.
Oh well, in that case, we mustn't disappoint them. Shall we go and see what they've prepared?
Lord, they're at the rear, the front is too full of people.
Well, if they're as good as people say they are, I might let them dance with me.  CALIGULA leads the way out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: CALIGULA steps into the covered way. CASSIUS and SABINUS stand waiting, swords drawn.

Dialogue.Line: What's this? I thought we were...
The watchword, butcher, is "Liberty!"
Oh no! ... No you can't, I'm a god! I'm a god! You can't kill me! ... Drusilla! I'm dying! Drusilla!
Finish him!
This is from our wives, Jove.
You fools! You've let them kill him! Your Emperor! After them!  CAESONIA (O.S.) Oh, Cassius. Cassius, what's happened? Where has everybody gone? No, not the baby! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An imposing hall, ransacked but still grand, echoes with the sounds of looting and excited shouts. SOLDIERS, a mix of Praetorian Guard and German mercenaries, swarm through the room, grabbing valuables. Senators cower in corners, fear etched on their faces.
The throne, once a symbol of absolute power, is now merely a convenient platform for plunder.
GRATUS, a burly Praetorian, shoves a senator aside as he rummages through a chest.
SERGEANT (O.S)
This way lads. The main room, hurry, There's some stuff in here. Hurry up, lads! Take what you can. Let's get out before the Germans come. Get anything you can take. Check it's got gold in it.
Gratus turns, spotting the SERGEANT.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Sergeant.
Yep?
Here's one of them. It's one of the assassins!  GRATUS grabs CLAUDIUS, who cowers and stammers.
N-no! Don't kill me, s-sir, I b-beg you! I had nothing to do with it!
You bastard. Kill our beloved Emperor, would you? Put us all out of work?  The SERGEANT pushes his way through the crowd.

Wait a minute, Gratus, that's not an assassin. It's the Emperor's uncle, Germanicus' lame old brother. He's harmless. Leave him alone, can't you see he's crippled. Come on, sir, get up. We won't harm you.  Claudius, relieved, struggles to his feet, leaning heavily on a nearby pillar.
Thank you.
There, you see, the lads are a bit angry, sir. Without an Emperor, there's no Praetorian Guard, and it's back to the army for the lot of us.
I m-must go and f-find my wife.
Of course, you must sir. Gratus, take a couple of lads and go with this gentlemen!  Gratus eyes Claudius with a strange look.
Why can't we have him for an Emperor?
What? Old Claudius? Don't be stupid, lad. He's a simpleton. He's...
I don't know, he's better than nothing.
No, no! I don't want to be Emperor! I want a Republic!  The Sergeant bursts out laughing.
You a member of the Imperial family, sir? Don't make me laugh! Hey, lads! We've found an Emperor!
No!  A GERMAN GUARD, hearing the commotion, approaches cautiously, his hand on his sword.
Das ist eine! Da achtung!
Wait a minute, Just a minute, Herman. That's our new Emperor. Kaiser! Emperor!
Ja?
Ja! Lift him up, lads! Long live the Emperor Claudius!  Praetorian Guards hoist Claudius onto their shoulders. He thrashes weakly, terrified.
No! Put me down! Put me down!
Oh, don't worry, sir, you'll get used to it. It's not such a bad life. Put this on him.  Gratus grabs a tattered purple robe from a pile of looted goods and throws it over Claudius.
Put me down! I don't want to be an Emperor! I w-want a Republic.

Don't keep saying that, sir. Not in front of the Germans, they'll slit your throat. Now, come on, smile. Smile. That's it, that's it. Look happy. Long live the Emperor!  Gratus forces Claudius's face into a grotesque smile.

Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor! Long live the Emperor!  The chant grows louder, more insistent, drowning out Claudius's feeble protests as he is paraded through the looted throne room.  FADE OUT.
